#Text=Cut Tennis Balls
#Text=Tennis balls can be used for more that just playing games .
#Text=When they ’re cut open , you can slide them onto furniture legs or walkers to protect your floors and move them around easier .
#Text=If you cut a tennis ball in half , you can use the halves as massagers to help alleviate foot and back pain .
#Text=Cutting a tennis ball is an easy process as long as you ’re careful not to cut yourself !
#Text=Steps
#Text=Cutting Tennis Balls for Furniture
#Text=Hold the tennis ball firmly against a solid surface .
#Text=Set the tennis ball on a surface that ’s knife-safe , such as a cutting board .
#Text=Grip the tennis ball in your non-dominant hand so the rounded edge of the seam faces up .
#Text=Use your ring finger and pinky to support the back of the ball so it does n’t roll away .
#Text=If you do n’t feel comfortable holding the ball while you cut it , secure the ball in a vise grip .
#Text=Poke the blade of a utility knife through the middle of the ball .
#Text=Hold the knife with your dominant hand so your index finger is along the top edge and pointing toward the blade .
#Text=Carefully poke the end of your knife in between the seams until it breaks into the center of the ball .
#Text=Make sure the blade is n’t pointed toward your fingers or you could accidentally cut yourself if the knife slips .
#Text=You may also use a craft knife , but it may not be as strong as a utility knife .
#Text=Cut a slit in the ball .
#Text=Move your blade up and down to saw through the ball ’s rubber .
#Text=Make a straight horizontal cut parallel to the seams that ’s about long .
#Text=When you ’re finished with the cut , pull your knife out of the ball .
#Text=Do n't make your slit any longer or else it could easily fall off of furniture legs .
#Text=Rotate the ball by 90 degrees and make another slit .
#Text=Turn the ball so the slit you cut is vertical when you look at it .
#Text=Press the tip of the knife to the left of the first slit near its midpoint .
#Text=Make a horizontal cut that crosses the first slit so it forms an X-shape .
#Text=Once your second slit is long , take your knife out .
#Text=Leave the ball near a window or well-ventilated area for 1 day to dry any moisture .
#Text=Sometimes , tennis balls have a small amount of moisture inside them that could damage furniture legs .
#Text=Set the ball on a windowsill so the cut faces down .
#Text=Let the ball dry out for about 1 day before putting it on anything .
#Text=Once the ball does n't have an odor , it 's ready to use .
#Text=Halving a Tennis Ball
#Text=Trace a line around the circumference of the ball .
#Text=Hold the ball steady on your work surface with your non-dominant hand .
#Text=Draw a straight line in the direction you want to cut on top of the ball with a pen .
#Text=Rotate the ball when you need to continue your line around its surface .
#Text=Make sure the ends of your line meet so you know it ’s straight .
#Text=If a pen does n’t work on your tennis ball , use a marker .
#Text=The marker line will be noticeable when you finish your cut .
#Text=Hold the ball from above against a hard surface .
#Text=Set the ball on a cutting board or another surface where you can easily use a knife .
#Text=Hold the ball with your non-dominant hand so all of your fingers are gripping it .
#Text=Keep 3 fingers on the front of the ball , and support the back side with your pinky and thumb .
#Text=Make sure your cut line is between your front and back fingers .
#Text=Imagine your hand is a claw so you ’re only grabbing the ball with the ends of your fingers .
#Text=Start your cut with a serrated knife .
#Text=Feed the blade of your knife underneath your hand so it ’s between your front and back fingers .
#Text=Use firm pressure as you saw back and forth along the cut line .
#Text=Continue cutting until you ’re halfway through the ball before removing your knife .
#Text=Stay attentive while you make your cut so you do n’t accidentally hurt yourself .
#Text=Rotate the ball to finish making your cut .
#Text=Turn the ball by 90 degrees along the line you drew and hold it firmly again .
#Text=Stick the blade of your knife into the cut you started and continue working along the line you drew .
#Text=Keep rotating the ball by 90 degrees and cutting until it ’s halved .
#Text=Turning the ball makes it easier to cut and helps ensure you ’re halves are the same size .
#Text=Finished .
#Text=Warnings
#Text=Never cut toward your fingers or else you may hurt yourself .
#Text=Things You ’ll Need
#Text=Cutting Tennis Balls for Furniture
#Text=Cutting board
#Text=Utility knife
#Text=Halving a Tennis Ball
#Text=Pen
#Text=Cutting board
#Text=Serrated knife
